IRS990.Desc: THE COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCES PREPARES STUDENTS OF ALL AGES AND BACKGROUNDS TO LIVE MORE FULFILLING LIVES, TO APPRECIATE AND CONTRIBUTE TO THE COMMUNITIES OF WHICH THEY ARE MEMBERS AND TO REACH THEIR ETHICAL, PERSONAL, INTELLECTUAL AND FINANCIAL GOALS. TO HELP ITS STUDENTS MAXIMIZE THEIR POTENTIAL, THE COLLEGE EMPHASIZES CRITICAL AND ANALYTICAL THINKING THROUGH A RIGOROUS "SUCCESS SKILLS" UNDERGRADUATE CORE PROGRAM IN WRITTEN AND ORAL COMMUNICATION, COMPUTING, ANALYZING, AND INTEGRATING. FACULTY SCHOLARSHIP SUPPORTS DIVERSIFIED LIBERAL ARTS CONCENTRATIONS AVAILABLE IN THE HUMANITIES, THE NATURAL SCIENCES AND THE SOCIAL SCIENCES, ALONG WITH GRADUATE PROGRAMS IN SEVERAL FIELDS, MOST OFFERING CAREER-RELATED PROFESSIONAL PROGRAM TRACKS AND PRACTICAL EXPERIENCE ON OR OFF CAMPUS. SEE SCHEDULE O FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: THE SAWYER BUSINESS SCHOOL (SBS) CREATES A LEARNING ENVIRONMENT THAT ENABLES STUDENTS TO EMERGE AS SUCCESSFUL LEADERS IN THE PRACTICE OF GLOBAL BUSINESS AND PUBLIC SERVICES. THE SBS VALUES EXCELLENCE IN EDUCATION AND RESEARCH, AND WORKS WITH ITS STUDENTS, ALUMNI, AND BUSINESS PARTNERS TO ACHIEVE THEIR GOALS. THE PROGRAMS ARE BUILT ON THE CORE VALUES OF PROMOTING OPPORTUNITY, EXCELLENCE, QUALITY TEACHING, INCLUSION AND COLLABORATION, AND EXCEPTIONAL SERVICE. SEE SCHEDULE O FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION.

ProgSrvcAccomActy3Grp.Desc: THE LAW SCHOOL IS DEDICATED TO WELCOMING STUDENTS FROM ALL BACKGROUNDS AND CIRCUMSTANCES AND EDUCATING THEM TO BECOME HIGHLY SKILLED AND ETHICAL LAWYERS WHO ARE WELL-PREPARED TO SERVE IN THEIR LOCAL COMMUNITIES, ACROSS THE NATION, AND AROUND THE WORLD. THE LAW SCHOOL SEEKS TO DEVELOP IN ITS STUDENTS THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO SERVE THE PROFESSION'S CHANGING NEEDS IN AN INCREASINGLY DIVERSE, GLOBAL, AND TECHNOLOGICALLY-DEPENDENT SOCIETY. THE LAW SCHOOL'S GOAL IS TO PROVIDE ITS STUDENTS WITH ACCESS TO AN EXCELLENT LEGAL EDUCATION, INSPIRE A COMMITMENT TO JUSTICE, AND PROVIDE ITS GRADUATES THE OPPORTUNITY TO ACHIEVE THEIR CAREER ASPIRATIONS.

Form990ScheduleAPartVIGrp.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: SCHEDULE A, PART II, LINE 10, EXPLANATION OF OTHER INCOME:
SCHEDULE A, PART II, LINE 10, EXPLANATION FOR OTHER INCOME:
Form990ScheduleAPartVIGrp.ExplanationTxt: OTHER INCOME IS PRIMARILY COMPRISED OF BOOKSTORE COMMISSIONS, THE CENTER FOR RESTORATIVE JUSTICE, THE FORFEITURE OF ACCRUED VACATION, AND OTHER MISCELLANEOUS INCOME.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: SUFFOLK UNIVERSITY PAYS PROFESSIONAL AND MEMBERSHIP DUES TO VARIOUS EDUCATIONAL ASSOCIATIONS WHICH MAY ENGAGE IN LOBBYING ACTIVITIES ON BEHALF OF THEIR MEMBERS.

OtherSecuritiesGrp.Desc: FUNDS HELD OR ADMINISTERED BY OTHERS

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE UNIVERSITY'S COLLECTIONS CONSIST OF WORKS OF ART, ARTIFACTS, RARE BOOKS, HISTORICAL DOCUMENTS, AND OTHER SIMILAR MATERIALS THAT ARE HELD FOR EDUCATIONAL, RESEARCH, SCIENTIFIC, AND CURATORIAL PURPOSES. EACH OF THE ITEMS IS CATALOGUED, PRESERVED, AND CARED FOR, AND ACTIVITIES VERIFYING THEIR EXISTENCE AND ASSESSING THEIR CONDITION ARE PERFORMED REGULARLY. AN EXAMPLE OF A COLLECTION HELD BY THE UNIVERSITY IS THE JOHN JOSEPH MOAKLEY ARCHIVE AND INSTITUTE. THE JOHN JOSEPH MOAKLEY ARCHIVE AND INSTITUTE AT SUFFOLK UNIVERSITY WAS ESTABLISHED IN 2001 UPON CONGRESSMAN MOAKLEY'S GIFT OF HIS PAPERS. THE INSTITUTE IS DEDICATED TO THE PRESERVATION, STUDY, INTERPRETATION, AND CELEBRATION OF CONGRESSMAN MOAKLEY'S LEGACY OF SERVICE AND POLITICAL AND PUBLIC POLICY LEADERSHIP THROUGH PROGRAMMING AND PROMOTION OF JOE MOAKLEY'S CONGRESSIONAL PAPERS. EXHIBIT PROGRAM: THE MOAKLEY INSTITUTE CURATES AND PRESENTS TWO TYPES OF EXHIBITS ON THE LIFE AND LEGACY OF CONGRESSMAN JOE MOAKLEY: GALLERY EXHIBITS AND TRAVELING EXHIBITS. CONGRESSMAN MOAKLEY PAPERS: THE CONGRESSMAN MOAKLEY PAPERS CONSIST OF 522 BOXES OF MATERIALS THAT DOCUMENT THE CONGRESSMAN'S EARLY LIFE, HIS WORLD WAR II SERVICE, HIS TERMS IN THE MASSACHUSETTS HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES AND SENATE, AND HIS SERVICE IN THE US CONGRESS. PRIMARILY, THE COLLECTION COVERS MOAKLEY'S CONGRESSIONAL CAREER FROM 1973 TO 2001 INCLUDING DOCUMENTS RELATED TO HIS LEGISLATIVE AND POLICY CAMPAIGNS CENTERED ON HUMAN RIGHTS, THE MOAKLEY COMMISSION IN EL SALVADOR, FIRE-SAFE CIGARETTES, AND HIS PROMOTION OF DISTRICT PROJECTS SUCH AS THE BOSTON HARBOR ISLANDS, THE BIG DIG, AND PRESERVATION OF HISTORIC SITES.

THE UNIVERSITY'S ENDOWMENT CONSISTS OF APPROXIMATELY 300 INDIVIDUAL FUNDS ESTABLISHED FOR A VARIETY OF PURPOSES INCLUDING BOTH DONOR-RESTRICTED ENDOWMENT FUNDS AND FUNDS DESIGNATED BY THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES TO FUNCTION AS ENDOWMENTS. THE MAJORITY OF THE FUNDS PROVIDE SCHOLARSHIPS AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO UNDERGADUATE, GRADUATE, AND LAW SCHOOL STUDENTS. SOME OF THE OTHER USES OF THE FUNDS INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO, SUPPORT FOR FELLOWSHIPS, THE CREATION AND FUNDING OF FACULTY CHAIRS, SUPPORT FOR VARIOUS UNIVERSITY CENTERS, AND SUPPORT FOR THE UNIVERSITY'S TEACHING AND RESEARCH ACTIVITIES. THE UNIVERSITY'S SPENDING POLICY IS DESIGNED TO PROVIDE THE UNIVERSITY A STABLE LEVEL OF FINANCIAL SUPPORT AND TO PRESERVE THE ENDOWMENT'S VALUE.

THE UNIVERSITY IS A NOT-FOR-PROFIT ORGANIZATION AND IS GENERALLY EXEMPT FROM FEDERAL AND STATE INCOME TAXES ON RELATED INCOME AS DESCRIBED IN SECTION 501(C)(3) OF THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE. THE UNIVERSITY IS NOT CURRENTLY UNDER EXAMINATION BY ANY TAXING JURISDICTIONS AND DOES NOT BELIEVE IT HAS ANY UNCERTAIN TAX POSITIONS. THE UNIVERSITY'S FEDERAL AND STATE TAX RETURNS ARE GENERALLY OPEN FOR EXAMINATION FOR THREE YEARS FOLLOWING THE DATE FILED.

CHANGE IN VALUE OF SPLIT INTEREST -40,699. POST RETIREMENT BENEFIT OBLIGATION -10,136. REVENUE REPORTED BY SUBSIDARY IN SPAIN 3,754,145. MADRID NON-OPERATING ACTIVITY -1,400,818. SUFFOLK NON-OPERATING ACTIVITY -1,395,473.
FINANCIAL AID 130,395,471.
EXPENSES REPORTED BY SUBSIDIARY IN SPAIN 3,964,925.
OTHER NON-OPERATING EXPENSES 50,994. FINANCIAL AID 130,395,471.

SUFFOLK UNIVERSITY DOES NOT DISCRIMINATE ON THE BASIS OF RACE, COLOR, NATIONAL ORIGIN, RELIGION, SEX, AGE, DISABILITY, SEXUAL ORIENTATION, GENDER IDENTITY, GENDER EXPRESSION, GENETIC INFORMATION, VIETNAM-ERA OR DISABLED-VETERAN STATUS IN ITS EMPLOYMENT, ADMISSION POLICIES, OR IN THE ADMINISTRATION OR OPERATION OF, OR ACCESS TO ITS ACADEMIC AND NON-ACADEMIC PROGRAMS AND POLICIES. IT DOES NOT DISCRIMINATE ON THE BASIS OF DISABILITY IN VIOLATION OF SECTION 504 OF THE REHABILITATION ACT OF 1973. THE UNIVERSITY PUBLISHES ITS RACIALLY NONDISCRIMINATORY POLICY ON THE UNIVERSITY'S WEBSITE, APPLICATIONS FOR EMPLOYMENT, AND STUDENT, STAFF AND FACULTY HANDBOOKS.

THE UNIVERSITY RECEIVES AID FOR STUDENTS FROM SUCH FEDERAL PROGRAMS AS PELL, SEOG, FEDERAL WORK STUDY, PERKINS, DIRECT LOANS, ETC. THE UNIVERSITY IS ALSO THE RECIPIENT OF SEVERAL FEDERAL AND STATE GRANTS FROM AGENCIES SUCH AS THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE PROGRAMS, NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION AND THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION, AMONG OTHERS.

ForeignIndividualsGrantsGrp.TypeOfAssistanceTxt: FOREIGN GRANTS PAID - EAST ASIA AND THE PACIFIC

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: ALL GRANTS ARE AWARDED BASED ON NEED AND/OR MERIT AND CONFORM TO FEDERAL, STATE, AND INSTITUTIONAL REGULATIONS. ELIGIBILITY IS BASED ON A THOROUGH REVIEW AND VERIFICATION OF A FAMILY'S INCOME, ASSETS, SIZE, AND NUMBER OF DEPENDENTS ENROLLED IN COLLEGE. ANNUAL EXPENDITURE REPORTS ARE SUBMITTED TO THE FEDERAL AND STATE GOVERNMENTS FOR REVIEW. THE FUND EXPENDITURES ARE REVIEWED FOR COMPLIANCE IN AN ANNUAL AUDIT CONDUCTED BY AN INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTING FIRM.
EXPENDITURES IN COLUMN (F) ARE BASED ON THE ACCRUAL METHOD OF ACCOUNTING.

THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO BOSTON PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT AGENCY, AS PART OF THE CITY OF BOSTON, WHICH ASSISTS THE ORGANIZATION TO DEVELOP DOWNTOWN BOSTON AND SURROUNDING NEIGHBORHOODS PURSUANT TO COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO EAST BOSTON HIGH SCHOOL FOR ITS ATHLETIC PROGRAMS. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO THE FUND FOR PARKS AND RECREATION IN BOSTON FOR UPKEEP OF ATHLETIC FIELDS USED BY THE UNIVERSITY AS WELL AS THE SURROUNDING NEIGHBORHOODS. PART III: ALL GRANTS AWARDED ARE BASED ON NEED AND/OR MERIT AND CONFORM TO FEDERAL, STATE, AND INSTITUTIONAL REGULATIONS. ELIGIBILITY IS BASED ON A THOROUGH REVIEW AND VERIFICATION OF A FAMILY'S INCOME, ASSETS, SIZE, AND NUMBER OF DEPENDENTS ENROLLED IN COLLEGE. ANNUAL EXPENDITURE REPORTS ARE SUBMITTED TO THE FEDERAL AND STATE GOVERNMENTS FOR REVIEW. THE FUND EXPENDITURES ARE REVIEWED FOR COMPLIANCE IN AN ANNUAL AUDIT CONDUCTED BY AN INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTING FIRM.

THE UNIVERSITY PAYS FOR CERTAIN TRAVEL EXPENSES FOR THE UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT'S SPOUSE, ONLY WHEN THAT TRAVEL IS PRIMARILY FOR BONA FIDE BUSINESS PURPOSES OF THE UNIVERSITY. TRAVEL EXPENSES FOR THE PRESIDENT AND HER SPOUSE ARE APPROVED BY THE CHAIRMAN OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES. THE HOUSING ALLOWANCE WAS RECEIVED BY THE UNIVERSITY'S PRESIDENT AND IS INCLUDED IN HER TAXABLE WAGES. SOCIAL CLUB DUES WERE PAID BY THE UNIVERSITY ON BEHALF OF AN OFFICER. THE DUES ARE NOT INCLUDED IN THE EMPLOYEE'S TAXABLE WAGES AS THE SOCIAL CLUB IS USED TO CONDUCT UNIVERSITY BUSINESS.

DURING AN EXECUTIVE SESSION OF THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE, THE COMMITTEE COMPLETED AN ANNUAL PERFORMANCE REVIEW OF THE PRESIDENT AND AGREED UPON A BONUS AMOUNT THAT REFLECTED HER PERFORMANCE DURING THE PRECEDING YEAR. CERTAIN OTHER INDIVIDUALS LISTED ON FORM 990, PART VII, SECTION A, LINE 1A RECEIVED BONUSES AS WELL.

TaxExemptBondsIssuesGrp.PurposeDesc: RETIRE TAXABLE LOAN AND FINANCE CAPITAL EXPENSES

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: PART I, COLUMN (F) - DESCRIPTION OF PURPOSE
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: BOND ISSUE A & B - THE SERIES 2009A BONDS WERE ISSUED ON 11/18/2009. BOND ISSUE C - THE SERIES 2010 BONDS WERE ISSUED ON 10/14/2020. BOND ISSUE D - THE LINE OF CREDIT WAS INCURRED ON 9/10/2019.

THE REBATE COMPUTATION DATE FOR THE 2017 BOND ISSUE WAS 4/30/2022. PART IV, LINE 2C, COLUMN B THE REBATE COMPUTATION DATE FOR THE 2019 BOND ISSUE WAS 4/30/2022. PART IV, LINE 2C, COLUMN C THE REBATE COMPUTATION DATE FOR THE 2020A BOND ISSUE WAS 4/30/2022. PART IV, LINE 2C, COLUMN D THE REBATE COMPUTATION DATE FOR THE 2021 BOND ISSUE WAS 4/30/2022.
THE ORGANIZATION IS REPORTING THE NUMBER OF CONTRIBUTIONS RECEIVED.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART I, LINE 1 AND PART III, LINE 1
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: DESCRIPTION OF ORGANIZATION MISSION: AT SUFFOLK UNIVERSITY WE ARE DRIVEN BY THE POWER OF EDUCATION, INCLUSION, AND ENGAGEMENT TO CHANGE LIVES AND POSITIVELY IMPACT COMMUNITIES. COMMITTED TO EXCELLENCE, WE PROVIDE STUDENTS WITH EXPERIENTIAL AND TRANSFORMATIONAL LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES THAT BEGIN IN THE CENTER OF BOSTON, REACH ACROSS THE GLOBE, AND LEAD TO EXTRAORDINARY OUTCOMES FOR OUR GRADUATES.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART III, LINE 4A AND 4B, PROGRAM SERVICE ACCOMPLISHMENTS:
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: REVENUES RELATED TO THE UNIVERSITY'S PROGRAM SERVICES ARE ALLOCATED BASED ON THE SCHOOL IN WHICH ACADEMIC COURSES ARE TAUGHT. EXPENSES ARE ALLOCATED BASED ON THE FTE ENROLLMENT IN THE RESPECTIVE SCHOOLS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION A, LINE 1A
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: IN THE INTERVALS BETWEEN MEETINGS OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES, THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE SHALL HAVE AND EXERCISE THE AUTHORITY OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES IN THE MANAGEMENT AND EXECUTION OF THE AFFAIRS OF SUFFOLK UNIVERSITY IN ALL MATTERS EXCEPT THOSE WITH RESPECT TO WHICH AUTHORITY IS GIVEN IN THE UNIVERSITY'S BYLAWS TO THE ADMINISTRATION AND FINANCE COMMITTEE AND EXCEPT THOSE WHICH PURSUANT TO LAW OR SPECIFIC SECTIONS OF THE BYLAWS REQUIRE THE VOTE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION B, LINE 11B
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE CONTROLLER OF SUFFOLK UNIVERSITY IS RESPONSIBLE FOR PROVIDING THE INFORMATION NECESSARY FOR THE UNIVERSITY'S TAX ADVISOR TO PREPARE FORM 990. RECOMMENDED CHANGES ARE DISCUSSED WITH SENIOR MANAGEMENT AND INCORPORATED INTO THE RETURN. THE DRAFT FORM IS THEN PROVIDED TO THE AUDIT, COMPLIANCE, AND RISK MANAGEMENT COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES SUFFICIENTLY IN ADVANCE OF THE FILING DEADLINE TO ENABLE A DETAILED AND CONSCIENTIOUS REVIEW BY ALL MEMBERS OF THE COMMITTEE WITH SENIOR MANAGEMENT AND THE UNIVERSITY'S TAX ADVISOR. ALL QUESTIONS AND CONCERNS OF THE AUDIT, COMPLIANCE, AND RISK MANAGEMENT COMMITTEE MEMBERS ARE ADDRESSED AND INCORPORATED INTO THE FORM AS APPROPRIATE. AFTER THE AUDIT, COMPLIANCE, AND RISK MANAGEMENT COMMITTEE REVIEW, ALL MEMBERS OF THE GOVERNING BODY ARE PROVIDED A LINK TO A PASSWORD-PROTECTED WEBSITE ON WHICH THE ENTIRE FORM 990 CAN BE VIEWED IN ADVANCE OF THE FILING DEADLINE. ALL QUESTIONS AND CONCERNS OF THE MEMBERS OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES ARE ADDRESSED BY THE INTERIM CFO AND TREASURER AND INCORPORATED INTO THE FORM 990 AS APPROPRIATE. AFTER ALL OF THE INPUT FROM THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES AND THE AUDIT, COMPLIANCE, AND RISK MANAGEMENT COMMITTEE HAS BEEN APPROPRIATELY ADDRESSED, THE INTERIM CFO AND TREASURER OF THE UNIVERSITY IS AUTHORIZED TO FILE THE FORM 990 WITH THE INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION B, LINE 12C
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE AUDIT, COMPLIANCE, AND RISK MANAGEMENT COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES IS RESPONSIBLE FOR OBTAINING A CONFLICT OF INTEREST DISCLOSURE STATEMENT FROM ALL BOARD MEMBERS, OFFICERS OF THE UNIVERSITY, AND ALL EMPLOYEES OF THE UNIVERSITY HOLDING CERTAIN POSITIONS AS DETERMINED BY THE AUDIT, COMPLIANCE AND RISK MANAGEMENT COMMITTEE, REFERRED TO AS COVERED PERSONS. THE DISCLOSURE STATEMENT IS TO BE COMPLETED UPON FIRST ACCEDING TO THE OFFICER POSITION, UPON MATERIAL CHANGE IN THE INFORMATION REQUESTED, AND IN JULY OF EACH YEAR. THE AUDIT, COMPLIANCE, AND RISK MANAGEMENT COMMITTEE PROVIDES THE BOARD WITH A SUMMARY REPORT OF ANY CONFLICT OF INTEREST AT LEAST ANNUALLY, AND MORE FREQUENTLY AS APPROPRIATE. THE AUDIT, COMPLIANCE, AND RISK MANAGEMENT COMMITTEE MAY INVITE THE COVERED PERSON TO MAKE A PRESENTATION AT A MEETING TO DISCUSS THE TRANSACTION. THE AUDIT, COMPLIANCE, AND RISK MANAGEMENT COMMITTEE WILL THEN DETERMINE BY A MAJORITY VOTE WHETHER THE TRANSACTION IS IN THE UNIVERSITY'S BEST INTEREST, AND WHETHER IT IS FAIR AND REASONABLE, AND THEREFORE WHETHER THE UNIVERSITY MAY OR MAY NOT ENTER INTO THE TRANSACTION.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION B, LINE 15
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: FOR THE COMPENSATION SETTING PROCESS OF THE PRESIDENT, THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES ENGAGED AN INDEPENDENT FIRM TO ANALYZE AND COMPARE THE COMPENSATION OF CEOS AT COMPARABLE INSTITUTIONS. A COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES WORKED WITH THE INDEPENDENT FIRM TO ANALYZE THE COMPENSATION DATA. AFTER REVIEWING THE RESULTS OF THE STUDY AND IN CONSULTATION WITH OUTSIDE COUNSEL, THE COMMITTEE PROPOSED COMPENSATION FOR THE PRESIDENT. A CONTRACT WAS PREPARED BY THE OUTSIDE COUNSEL, WHICH WAS VOTED ON AND APPROVED AT A MEETING OF THE FULL BOARD OF TRUSTEES. FUTURE AMENDMENT/CONTRACT CHANGES ARE REVIEWED BY COUNSEL. FOR THE COMPENSATION SETTING PROCESS OF OTHER OFFICERS AND KEY EMPLOYEES, THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES ENGAGED AN INDEPENDENT FIRM TO ANALYZE AND COMPARE THE COMPENSATION OF INDIVIDUALS IN COMPARABLE POSITIONS AT COMPARABLE INSTITUTIONS. A COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES WORKED WITH THE INDEPENDENT FIRM TO ANALYZE THE COMPENSATION DATA. THE COMPENSATION FOR ALL OFFICERS AND KEY EMPLOYEES WITH MULTI-YEAR CONTRACTS IS VOTED ON AND APPROVED AT A MEETING OF THE FULL BOARD OF TRUSTEES. FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION B, LINE 16: THE UNIVERSITY PARTICIPATES IN A JOINT VENTURE AGREEMENT THAT HELPS UNIVERSITIES EXPAND INTERNATIONAL RECRUITMENT AND ENSURES INTERNATIONAL STUDENTS' SUCCESS ON CAMPUS THROUGH PROVEN PROGRAMS THAT BETTER PREPARE STUDENTS FOR ACADEMIC SUCCESS. THE JOINT VENTURE INCLUDES TWO PARTIES AND IS GOVERNED BY A EIGHT MEMBER BOARD OF DIRECTORS COMPRISING FOUR REPRESENTATIVES FROM EACH ORGANIZATION. PRIOR TO SIGNING, THE AGREEMENT WAS REVIEWED BY INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL LEGAL COUNSEL TO ENSURE IT COMPLIED WITH TAX REGULATIONS. THE REVENUE RECOGNIZED PURSUANT TO THE AGREEMENT IS CONSIDERED IN PART VIII AS RELATED OR EXEMPT FUNCTION REVENUE. THE AGREEMENT ALSO INCLUDES A PROVISION FOR TERMINATING THE AGREEMENT IN THE EVENT THAT CONTINUATION OF THE AGREEMENT WOULD CAUSE THE UNIVERSITY TO LOSE ITS TAX-EXEMPT STATUS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION C, LINE 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: ALL REQUESTS FOR GOVERNING DOCUMENTS, CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY, FINANCIAL STATEMENTS, AND TAX RETURNS ARE RECEIVED BY THE PRESIDENT AND/OR VICE PRESIDENT'S OFFICES AND ARE TURNED OVER TO THE INTERIM CFO AND TREASURER'S OFFICE FOR IMMEDIATE RESPONSE. TAX RETURNS AND FINANCIAL STATEMENTS ARE ALSO AVAILABLE ON THE MASSACHUSETTS ATTORNEY GENERAL AND GUIDESTAR WEBSITES.
